questions.text: Which of the following is not bacteriostatic:
questions.solution:
All cell wall inhibitors for eg. Vancomycin are bactericidal in nature

List of bactericidal and bacteriostatic drugs:

Vancomycin

It is a glycopeptide antibiotic discovered in 1956 as a penicillin substitute which assumed special significance due to efficacy against MRSA, Strep. viridans, Enterococcus and Cl. difficile. Bactericidal action is exerted only on gram-positive cocci, Neisseria, Clostridia and diphtheroids.

All Protein synthesis inhibitors are bacteriostatic in nature except:

  • Macrolides(high dose)
  • Aminoglycosides
  • Retapamulin(high dose)
  • Chloramphenicol

Option A: Linezolid is a Oxazolidinone and is a protein synthesis inhibitor

Option B: Clindamycin is a Lincosamide and is a protein synthesis inhibitor

Option D: Erythromycin is a macrolide which in therapeutic doses is bacteriostatic but in high doses may act as a bactericidal drug.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of basiliximab is:
questions.solution:
IL-2 receptor antagonist

The CD-25 molecule is expressed on the surface of immunologically activated, but not resting T-cells. The CD-25 acts as a high affinity receptor for IL-2 through which cell proliferation and differentiation are promoted. Some anti CD-25 antibodies have been developed as IL-2 receptor antagonists to specifically arrest the activated T-cells.

Daclizumab: It is a highly humanized chimeric monoclonal anti CD-25 antibody which binds to and acts as IL-2receptor antagonist. Combined with glucocorticoids, calcineurinantagonists and/or azathioprine/MMF, it is used to prevent renal and other transplant rejection reactions.

Basiliximab: This is another anti CD-25 antibody with higher affinity for the IL-2 receptor, but shorter plasma t½ (1 week). Clinical use of basiliximab is similar to that of daclizumab.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Sacubitril?
questions.solution:
Sacubitril: It is an orally active Neutral Endopeptidase(NEP) inhibitor which increases the blood levels of Natriuretic Peptides and other vasodilator peptides resulting in natriuresis, diuresis, vascular relaxation, lowering of AngII as well as aldosterone levels. Combined with Valsartan, it affords symptomatic improvement in CHF patients.

Option A: ACE inhibitors: Captopril, Lisinopril etc.

Option C: Endothelin antagonist: Ambrisentan, Macitentan etc.

Option D: Angiotensin receptor blocker: Valsartan, Telmisartan etc.

questions.text: Testing of HLA-B 5701 is recommended prior to initiation of this antiretroviral agent:
questions.solution:
Genotyping for HLA-B5701has been shown to eliminate the risk for severe skin reactions (such as the Stevens-Johnson syndrome) during treatment with the antiretroviral agent abacavir

Untoward Effects and Drug Interactions.

The most important adverse effect of Abacavir is a unique and potentially fatal hypersensitivity syndrome characterized by fever, abdominal pain, and other GI complaints; a mild maculopapular rash; and malaise or fatigue. Respiratory complaints (cough, pharyngitis, dyspnea); musculoskeletal complaints; headache; and paresthesias are less common.

The hypersensitivity syndrome (2%-9% of patients) results from a genetically mediated immune response linked to both the HLA-B*5701 locus and the M493T allele in the heat-shock locus Hsp70-Hom.

Steven Johnson syndrome is associated with 3 important drugs and their genotyping is as follows:

  • Carbamazepine, Phenytoin: HLA B1502
  • Abacavir: HLA B5701
  • Allopurinol: HLA B5801

Amphotericin B (AMB)

It is obtained from Streptomyces nodosus.

Mechanism of action

Polyene antibiotics have high affinity for ergosterol present in fungal cell membranes. They combine with it, get inserted into the membrane and several polyene molecules together orient themselves in such a way as to form a 'micropore'. The hydrophilic side forms the interior of the pore through which ions, amino acids and other water-soluble substances move out. The micropore is stabilized by membrane sterols which fill up the spaces between the AMB molecules on the lipophilic side-constituting the outer surface of the pore. Thus, cell permeability is markedly increased.

questions.text: Most common agent among the following which is associated with agranulocytosis is:
questions.solution:
Alkylating Agents

All alkylating agents and related drugs (procarbazine, dacarbazine and platinum compounds) are CCNS drugs and thus act on both resting as well as dividing cells. These drugs alkylate nucleophilic groups on DNA bases (N7 of guanine is most susceptible) and may lead to cross-linking of bases, abnormal base-pairing and DNA strand breakage.

Gastrointestinal distress, bone marrow suppression, alopecia, secondary leukemias and sterility are common adverse effects of all the alkylating agents.

Its antipsychotic activity has been ascribed to a combination of D2 + 5-HT2 receptor blockade. In addition, it has high affinity for α1, α2 and H1 receptors: blockade of these may contribute to efficacy as well as side effects like postural hypotension.

Prolactin levels rise disproportionately during risperidone therapy, but it is less epileptogenic than clozapine, though frequently causes agitation.

questions.text: The given drug lacks intrinsic activity against anaerobes, and its resistance occurs most commonly due to inactivation by enzyme:
questions.solution:
Common properties of Aminoglycosides

  1. All are used as sulfate salts, which are highly water soluble; solutions are stable for months.
  2. They ionize in solution; are not absorbed orally; distribute only extracellularly; do not penetrate the brain or CSF.
  3. All are excreted unchanged in urine by glomerular filtration.
  4. All are bactericidal and more active at alkaline pH.
  5. They act by interfering with bacterial protein synthesis.
  6. All are active primarily against aerobic gram negative bacilli and do not inhibit anaerobes.
  7. There is only partial cross resistance among them.
  8. They have a relatively narrow margin of safety.
  9. All exhibit ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity.

MECHANISM OF RESISTANCE

Resistance to aminoglycosides is acquired by one of the following mechanisms:

  • Acquisition of cell membrane bound modifying enzymes which phosphorylate/adenylate or acetylate the antibiotic.
  • Mutation decreasing the affinity of ribosomal proteins that normally bind the aminoglycoside: this mechanism can confer high degree resistance
  • Decreased efficiency of the aminoglycoside transporting mechanism: either the pores in the outer coat become less permeable or the active transport is interfered.

questions.text: Which antiviral drug is used in both HIV and hepatitis B:
questions.solution:
Emtricitabine (FTC) It is a fluorinated cytidine analogue which is converted intracellularly by cellular kinases into its triphosphate which acts as the HIV reverse transcriptase inhibitor.

Like lamivudine, it is also active against HBV, but should not be used in HIV-HBV co-infected patients because sudden stoppage of therapy can cause rebound exacerbation of hepatitis.

Drugs used in both Hep B and HIV:

  • Lamivudine
  • Emtricitabine
  • Tenofovir

  • Also aPTT monitoring is a must for Unfractionated Heparin.
  • PT/INR monitoring is required in Warfarin

Monitoring is not required in other anticoagulant drugs.

Lepirudin is a recombinant forms of hirudin. Desirudin is indicated for thromboprophylaxis in patients undergoing elective hip replacement surgery. Both desirudin and lepirudin are also used for treating thrombosis in the setting of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.

Desirudin and lepirudin are eliminated by the kidneys; the t1/2 is about 2 h after subcutaneous administration and about 10 min after intravenous infusion. Both drugs should be used cautiously in patients with decreased renal function, and serum creatinine and aPTT should be monitored daily.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of colchicine in acute Gout?
questions.solution:
Colchicine is neither analgesic nor antiinflammatory, it specifically suppresses gouty inflammation. It does not inhibit the synthesis or promote the excretion of uric acid.(Option A,B,D ruled out)

Colchicine does not affect phagocytosis of urate crystals, but inhibits release of chemotactic factors and of the glycoprotein, thus suppressing the subsequent events. By binding to fibrillar protein tubulin, it inhibits granulocyte migration into the inflamed joint and thus interrupts the vicious cycle. Other actions of colchicine are:

(a) Antimitotic: causes metaphase arrest by binding to microtubules of mitotic spindle.

(b) Increases gut motility through neural mechanisms.

questions.text: Colonoscopy performed on a 25 year old woman with an eating disorder showed dark brown to black pigmentary deposit in the lining of the large intestine. Histopathology of biopsy revealed pigment laden macrophages within the lamina propria. The woman on probing revealed the use of laxatives for 9 months to lose weight. What could be the probable laxative agent that could have caused these findings?
questions.solution:
Purgative abuse

Purgatives are often self prescribed and taken without consulting a physician. Some individuals are obsessed with using purgatives regularly. This may be the reflection of a psychological problem.

Drawbacks of purgative abuse are:

  1. Fluid and electrolyte imbalance, especiallyhypokalaemia.
  2. Steatorrhoea, malabsorption syndrome.
  3. Protein losing enteropathy.
  4. Spastic colitis
  5. Melanosis coli(Specific side effect of Senna)

The active principle of Senna stimulates the myenteric plexus to increase peristalsis and decrease segmentation. They also promote secretion and inhibit salt and water absorption in the colon. Skin rashes, fixed drug eruption are the occasional adverse effects. Regular use for 4-12 months causes colonic atony and mucosal pigmentation (melanosis).

questions.text: You are the son of the owner of XYZ pharmaceuticals Pvt.Ltd. You have joined medicine and the company is now into making a different drug. The marketing head and the chief researcher, while waiting to meet your father, asks you this pharmacological question. A drug that binds to a receptor at a site distinct from the active site and alters the affinity of the receptor for the endogenous ligand is called as? And gives you the following options. Which would you pick?
questions.solution:
Allosteric modulators are compounds that bind to a site on a receptor distinct from the active (orthosteric) site, inducing conformational changes that alter the receptor's activity. These modulators do not directly activate the receptor but influence its response to endogenous ligands or agonists. Here are the key features of allosteric modulators:

  1. Binding to an Allosteric Site
    • Distinct from the Orthosteric Site: Allosteric modulators bind to a site different from the active site where endogenous ligands (e.g., neurotransmitters, hormones) bind.
    • Conformational Changes: Binding at this site induces a change in the receptor's shape, which affects the receptor's ability to interact with its endogenous ligand.
  2. Types of Allosteric Modulators
    • Positive Allosteric Modulators (PAMs):
      • Enhance the activity of the receptor when the endogenous ligand is present.
      • Increase the potency (lower EC50) or efficacy (higher maximal response) of the endogenous ligand.
    • Negative Allosteric Modulators (NAMs):
      • Decrease the activity of the receptor when the endogenous ligand is present.
      • Reduce the potency or efficacy of the endogenous ligand.
    • Silent Allosteric Modulators (SAMs):
      • Bind to the allosteric site but do not alter receptor activity on their own.
      • Can block the effects of other allosteric modulators without affecting the receptor's response to its endogenous ligand.
  3. Saturability
    • Allosteric modulation is usually saturable. At a certain point, increasing the concentration of the modulator no longer increases its effect due to the finite number of allosteric binding sites.
  4. Ceiling Effect
    • Allosteric modulators often exhibit a "ceiling effect," where the maximum response they can achieve is limited. This helps reduce the risk of overstimulation or excessive inhibition of the receptor.
  5. Selective Modulation
    • Allosteric modulators often display greater subtype selectivity than orthosteric ligands because allosteric sites tend to be less conserved across receptor subtypes.
  6. Context-Dependent Effects
    • The effect of an allosteric modulator can depend on the presence and concentration of the endogenous ligand, as well as the physiological context (e.g., receptor state, cell type).
  7. Non-Competitive Nature
    • Allosteric modulators are generally non-competitive with orthosteric ligands because they bind to a separate site. This can make them useful in situations where competitive inhibitors fail due to high endogenous ligand concentrations.
  8. Potential for Biased Modulation
    • Allosteric modulators can preferentially stabilize certain receptor conformations, potentially leading to biased signaling. This means they can selectively modulate specific signaling pathways linked to the receptor.

Examples:

  • Benzodiazepines (e.g., diazepam) as PAMs of GABAA_AA receptors.
  • Cinacalcet as a PAM of the calcium-sensing receptor.
  • Maraviroc as a NAM of the CCR5 receptor in HIV treatment
